document.docAuthor: Khandekar, Akshay, Thackeray, Tejas & Agarwal, Ishan
document.docTitle: Cnemaspis uttaraghati Khandekar & Thackeray & Agarwal 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A novel small-bodied rupicolous Cnemaspis Strauch, 1887 (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from the northern Western Ghats, Maharashtra, India, with comments on the status of C. indraneildasii, Bauer 2000

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A novel small-bodied rupicolous Cnemaspis Strauch, 1887 (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from the northern Western Ghats, Maharashtra, India, with comments on the status of C. indraneildasii, Bauer 2000

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype .
NRC-AA-1122 (AK 1233), adult male, from Kedareshwar caves on Harishchandragad mountain in Kalsubai-Harishchandragad Wildlife Sanctuary , ( 19.392Â° N , 73.779Â° E ; ca .
1200 m asl
.), Ahmednagar district , Maharashtra state , India , collected by Santosh Saste , Vaibhav Patil and Yogesh Satam on
27 October 2019
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratypes .
BNHS 2799 (AK 1234), adult male, NRC-AA-1123 (AK 1235)
,
BNHS 2800 (AK 1236), adult females, same collection and data as holotype
.

Etymology. The specific epithet is used as a noun in apposition and is derived from the Sanskrit â€˜uttaraâ€™ for north and â€˜ghatâ€™ for mountains, as this mountain locality represents the currently known northern limit of
Cnemaspis
distribution in the Western Ghats.

subSubSection.paragraph: Suggested Common Names. Northern dwarf gecko or Harishchandragad dwarf gecko.

Diagnosis: A small-sized
Cnemaspis
, snout to vent length less than 39 mm ( n =4). Dorsal pholidosis heterogeneous; weakly keeled, granular scales intermixed with large, weakly keeled, regularly arranged tubercles, enlarged tubercles gradually increasing in size towards flank, lowest row largest, spine-like; eight or nine rows of dorsal tubercles at mid-body, 7â€“10 paravertebral tubercles between forelimb and hindlimb insertions; ventral scales smooth, sub-imbricate, sub-equal from chest to vent, 27â€“32 scales across belly at mid-body, 124â€“132 longitudinal scales from mental to cloaca; subdigital scansors smooth, mostly entire, unnotched; 10â€“12 lamellae under digit I of manus and 10 or 11 lamellae under digit I of pes, 17 or 18 lamellae under digit IV of manus and 19â€“22 lamellae under digit IV of pes; males with four femoral pores on each thigh separated medially by 22â€“24 poreless scales ( n =2); dorsal pholidosis of tail with strongly keeled, granular scales, similar in size and shape to granular scales on mid-body dorsum, gradually becoming larger, flattened, imbricate posteriorly, intermixed with enlarged, strongly keeled, distinctly pointed, conical tubercles forming whorls, six tubercles in first eight whorls; median row of subcaudals smooth, slightly enlarged, regularly arranged with condition of two slightly larger scales alternating with a large divided scale. Dorsal colouration greenish-brown with six dark vertebral blotches running from the occiput to the sacrum, speckled with fine saffron granules, limbs with light yellow bands.

Comparison with peninsular Indian congeners.
Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from all other Indian congeners on the basis of the following differing or non-overlapping characters: small-sized
Cnemaspis SVL
36â€“39 mm ( versus medium-sized
Cnemaspis SVL
40â€“50 mm in
C. anandani Murthy, Anandan, Sengupta & Deepak
,
C. bangara Agarwal, Thackeray, Pal & Khandekar
,
C . boiei (Gray)
,
C. chengodumalaensis Cyriac, Palot, Deuti & Umesh
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,
C . wynadensis (Beddome)
,

, and
C. thackerayi Khandekar, Gaitonde & Agarwal
); large-sized
Cnemaspis SVL
> 50 mm in

Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.
closely resembles members of
girii
clade (
C. ajijae
,
C. amba
,
C. flaviventralis
,
C. girii
,
C. koynaensis
,
C. limayei
,
C. mahabali
). However, it can be further distinguished from all by having 7â€“10 paravertebral tubercles between forelimb and hindlimb insertions ( versus 17â€“22 paravertebral tubercles between forelimb and hindlimb insertions in
C. ajijae
and
C. amba
; 18 in
C. flaviventralis
, 20â€“22 in
C. girii
, 18â€“25 in
C. koynaensis
and 13â€“15 in
C. limayei
); eight or nine rows of dorsal tubercles at mid-body ( versus 11â€“14 rows of dorsal tubercles at mid-body in
C. amba
, 12 or 13 in
C. flaviventralis
, 12â€“14 in
C. girii
, and 10â€“14 in
C. koynaensis
); 27â€“32 ventral scales across belly at mid-body ( versus 22â€“24 ventral scales across belly at mid-body in
C. amba
, 20â€“26 in
C. koynaensis
, and 26 in
C. mahabali
); 124â€“132 longitudinal ventral scales from mental to cloaca ( versus 141â€“149 longitudinal ventral scales from mental to cloaca in
C. amba
, and 133â€“139 in
C. girii
); 17 or 18 lamellae under digit IV of manus ( versus 15 or 16 lamellae under digit IV of manus in
C. ajijae
,
C. flaviventralis
and
C. mahabali
, 15 in
C. limayei
); SVL up to 36â€“39 mm ( versus maximum SVL < 34 mm in
C. amba
,
C. girii
,
C. koynaensis
,
C. limayei
,
C. mahabali
).

Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.

Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.

TABLE 3. Mensural (mm) data for the type series of
Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.
Abbreviations are listed in Materials and Methods. * = tail incomplete.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Variation and additional information from type series.
Mensural and meristic data for the type series is given in Table 3 & 4 respectively. There are two male and two female specimens ranging in size from 36.5 mm to 38.9 mm . All specimens resemble the holotype except as follows: two internasal scales separate supranasals on snout in NRC-AA-1123 and BNHS 2800 ; a two postnasals on each side in BNHS 2799 , NRC-AA-1123 and BNHS 2800 ; outer postmentals bordered by four gular scales on each side in BNHS 2799 outer postmental bordered by four gular scales on right and three on left in NRC-AA-1123 and BNHS 2800 . Two paratypes â€”NRC-AA-1123 and BNHS 2800 with original and complete tails, slightly longer than body (TL/ SVL 1.13 and 1.12 respectively); BNHS 2799 with tail incomplete and regenerated tail tip, detached from the body, slightly shorter than body (TL/ SVL 0.76) ( Figure 6A ). All paratypes closely agree with the holotype in overall colouration except NRC-AA-1123 with dorsal ground colour of mid-body dorsum olive greenish, vertebral blotches and either side of flank heavily speckled with fine saffron granules ( Figure 5B ); BNHS 2800 is slightly paler than holotype ( Figure 5C ); colouration of the regenerated tail of BNHS 2799 is brown, lacking bands ( Figure 6A )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. Type series of
Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.
from left to right: BNHS 2799, NRC-AA-1123 and BNHS 2800. Scale bar 10 mm; photos by Akshay Khandekar.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and Natural history.
Cnemaspis uttaraghati
sp. nov.
is so far known only from the type locality, Harishchandragad mountain, in Kalsubai-Harishchandragad Wildlife Sanctuary,Ahmednagar district of Maharashtra at an elevation of ca. 1200 m asl. ( Figure 1 ). The individuals of the new species were encountered during a single day of fieldwork in the afternoon (1330â€“1445 hrs.). All four individuals were seen active, only on vertical basaltic rocks < 2m height, inside man-made caves ( Figure 7B ). A communal egg-laying site containing 11 hatched eggs and a single dark coloured unhatched egg (probably unviable) were seen on a horizontal rock face at approximately 3m height ( Figure 7C ). These caves are located on a high elevation (~ 1200 m asl.) basaltic plateau, predominantly covered by sparse scrubs and grasses on the top and semi-evergreen forest patches on the slopes ( Figure 7A ).
Hemidactylus maculatus DumÃ©ril & Bibron
, and
H. murrayi Gleadow
are the only two other gecko species that were observed in sympatry with the new species.
